Package doa.engine.sound

Class DoaSoundClip

java.lang.Object
doa.engine.sound.DoaSoundClip
public final class DoaSoundClip extends Object
Easy use version of Clip. Houses a Clip object and some necessary methods and utilities to quickly play, pause and stop arbitrary sound clips.
Since:
DoaEngine 1.1
Version:
3.0
Author:
Doga Oruc
See Also:
Clip

      public static final int FOREVER
      Constant for looping forever.

  • Constructor Details

    • DoaSoundClip

      public DoaSoundClip()

  • Method Details

    • loop

      public void loop​(int count)
      Loops the sound clip this object will play count times. If the clip is to be looped forever (or until it is stopped), use FOREVER.
      Parameters:
      count - loop count

    • play

      public void play()
      Plays the sound clip this object will play from the beginning.

    • stop

      public void stop()
      Stops the sound clip. This method will set the microsecond position of the clip to 0.

    • pause

      public void pause()
      Pauses the sound clip. This method will not change the microsecond position of the clip.

    • resume

      public void resume()
      Resumes the sound clip from the microsecond position.

    • getMicrosecondPosition

      public long getMicrosecondPosition()
      Returns the position of the playhead in terms of microseconds. 1 second = 1.000.000 microseconds.
      Returns:
      playhead position

    • setMicrosecondPosition

      public void setMicrosecondPosition​(long microsecondPosition)
      Sets the position of the playhead in terms of microseconds. 1 second = 1.000.000 microseconds. For example, passing 10.000.000 into this method will result in this clip forwarding to the 10th second.
      Parameters:
      microsecondPosition - new playhead position

    • getVolume

      public float getVolume()
      Returns the volume at which this clip is/will be playing at. The returned value is always between 0 and 1 inclusive.
      Returns:
      the volume of the clip

    • setVolume

      public void setVolume​(float volume)
      Sets the volume level. The parameter volume must be in the range [0, 1]. When volume = 0, clip is muted. When volume = 1, clip is playing at max volume. The volume is linear, not logarithmic.

      There appears to be a slight delay for the volume to change from its old value to its new value. This is possibly due to the internal workings of javax.sound.sampled package and has nothing to do with DoaEngine. Programmers should not rely on fast volume switches, instead they should make your sound designer do that in their DAW.
      Parameters:
      volume - the new value of the volume level
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if newVolume is not in range [0, 1]
